I have a somewhat different takeon acceleration: some kids are slightly later bloomers. And once you're off that advanced chronological track, you can't get back on. My kid wasn't recommended for accelerated math but self-selected (her idea, not mine--her grades were spotty but her NYS math scores were strong). She had two A's and two B's. Her teacher did not recommend that she continue, but again, she insisted. She didn't do the honors route, but she did continue with math and is now taking calculus. Is she a fabulous math student? No, but she's reasonably strong and she's gotten the exposure--and she's also confident about her math skills. And frankly, I've seen a tendency for teachers to recommend only the very strongest students (and to push out as many of the midrange or marginal students as possible).

I have to say, though, in the case of the student in the article, it seems pretty clear the girl should downtrack, especially since it's early days and she's already struggling so much. And if I were the parents, I'd forget about the fact that they'd pushed for the placement originally. They had what seemed valid reasons for self-selecting. It didn't work out. Nobody wants the kid to suffer and hate math.

The power of the self serving rich to cut their own taxes must be curbed.

This is not a minor economic issue. It is at the heart of who has power in the US and elsewhere. Here, the rich pay virtually no tax on inheritance because taxes on property are zero. They pay about 25% less tax rate on income because of things like low rates for capital gains.

Liberals, Progressives and indeed all Americans must fight against the power of the wealthy, especially those who have inherited it rather than earned it. Thomas Jefferson felt so strongly about it that he outlawed extreme inheritances when he was governor of Virginia.

Today, we must tax both capital gains and inheritances as if they were ordinary income. We should not continue to allow the undeserving rich to pay about half the tax rate that middle class earners pay on equivalent wages and salaries.

The death spiral has started and it must be stopped. Low taxes on wealth lead to the rich being more rich, which enables them to purchase the votes of more legislators, who then lower their taxes further.

This simple point should be the focus of liberal politics. People who do not make this point should no longer be supported by liberals. For instance, Obama's cowardly extension of the Bush tax cuts should lead to less support for him, even though he is a better choice than the Republican alternative. America deserves better.

My information concerning Veblen is that when it came to sharing other men's wives, he was very much a socialist.

A bit misleading, certainly if one wants to give Veblen his due. In the same book in which he articulated his seminal notion "Conspicuous Consumption," Veblen describes a related phenomenon, "Pecuniary Emulation," which is where society at large imitates the wealthy and their consumption patterns.

The author flatters herself as she states, as if we are ill-read, that the “aspirational class, as I call it" imitates the wealthy.

This was part and parcel of Veblen's original thesis. The germinal idea here is Veblen's idea of the essential "invidiousness" of social life. Conspicuousness is not for its own sake; it exists to be emulated, and to dare emulation.

A scholar's comment, pardon.

Your argument is that Wilcox et al.’s estimate of loss opportunity is dynamic, a path to loss opportunity which, because it may not be fully realized until some point in the future, can be averted to restore whatever full employment is at some point x on that path, if we adopt the appropriate expansive, Keynesian monetary and fiscal policies. Therefore, premature tightening of monetary policy now, prior to any signs of demand exceeding capacity, would be disastrous, especially since the Fed has the tools to notice inflation induced by excessive demand and thus reduce the monetary base at the first sign of inflation.

But what if Wilcox's estimate is already realized or fully enough realized or, at this point, is inevitable? That is, what if we've already done grievous damage to our economy's productive capacity? Well, then the case is made for restoring full employment at our instant productive capacity and for restoring our productive capacity. And fortunately both of those things require the same Keynesian remedy, that is, investment in both human and physical capital to restore potential GDP to what it was before the disastrous policy of austerity disastrously reduced our economy's productive capacity.

And economic research has taught us what that schedule of investments is: Investments in education, healthcare, infrastructure, R&D, etc., which make the greatest increases in our output and potential output. So either way monetary and fiscal tightening is bad policy.

If you are over  55 you are not paying for maternity and newborn care.  Your premium is based on your age and the average health care costs of a person in your age group. The fact that the policies are required to cover maternity care, when applicable, does not affect your premium in any way.  Insurance premiums are based purely on numerical averages and probabilities.  If you are past childbearing age the insurance company is well aware of that and is not charging you for maternity care.

Really, Medicare a financially broke system, and you want more people to 'buy in' at less then cost prices?  Give me a break, for broke I am.  Best we just wait out Obamacare for the next five years, for it will take that long to fully realize its impact on the healthcare system, including all the unintended consequences.  Any tinkering with the ACA in any form or fashion would be disastrous. The IRS parts of the ACA need to play out, including its ability to collect the tax penalties.  The credit and collections issues of Exchange plan payments need to play out. The latter is a big issue for an Exchange plan cannot cancel your coverage unless you payments are 90 over due, and nothing will stop a person from getting a new policy on the 90th day, a scam in the making.

Lookahead

You say

"The obvious next step is to allow those over 55 to buy into the Medicare system. The cost was estimated at $4,722 a person back in 2009, probably higher now."

The cost to whom? I assume you mean $4800 a year to the 55/65-year old individual. I cannot figure out where that estimate would have come from since the implicit Medicare premium is over $800 a month (adding together the Part B premium we do pay, 3 times that premium because we seniors are supposed to pay 25% of Part B's cost, and the premium people who don't qualify for Part A pay if they want to "buy in" to Part A). It sounds like your estimate only covers Part B.

And for the $800 a month you get Medicare, insurance with no catastrophic coverage, which Obamacare does have, no annual out of pocket limit, which Obamacare does have, no drug coverage, which Obamacare does have, no vision/dental/aural coverage (not sure if Obamacare has that), and higher deductibles and co-pays than the ones everyone -- including you apparently -- is complaining that Obamcare has. Aftter which you still pay for almost half your health care costs.

Tell me again why you want everyone to have Medicare. Tell me again why you are a "big supporter of the ACA."

I am a big supporter of the ACA as a step forward toward universal health care access. As much as I deplore the current bloated, wasteful, profit seeking system, going in a single step to a public single payer plan would have been disastrously disruptive to the health care sector, which is 18% of our economy.

And going back to a system in which only the healthy or fortuitously employed could buy or maintain insurance is not an option.

But the affordability issue for who do not qualify for subsidies is real, especially for those over 50. The NY Times Editorial Board continues to insist that old policies were inadequate. But the President has already acknowledged the unintended consequence that some new policies are not as good (same essential benefits except maternity, higher deductible and OOP caps) and cost up to double in our case.

The obvious next step is to allow those over 55 to buy into the Medicare system. The cost was estimated at $4,722 a person back in 2009, probably higher now. That would have seemed too high until the 2014 ACA rates for far less coverage were published.

Insurance companies will protest but they aren't going to get many 55+ people without subsidies to accept the new plans anyway, in our case premiums and OOP totaling $22,500, an increase of over $10,000.

There is only one way from here, forward.

To NYHuguenot in NC:  You're going to pay a heck of lot more than $22000 if your wife has a stroke, needs a surgery or almost anything involving more than one night in a hospital.  At any age, life can turn on a dime and at our age, that is even more true.  Keep your fingers and toes crossed she remains healthy.

I can think of millions who will have "smiles on their faces" when they find they are getting better or even first-time health insurance for the same or less than they were paying.  Your rhetoric is completely overblown.

I am sorry, but many of the comments against my post are wrong. People had policies that they liked. That covered their needs and was affordable. The president PROMISED they could keep it.
